data.text: How Much Luggage Do You Carry when Cycle Touring?

Is it just me, or do others look at some bikes and think, ‚Äòthat‚Äôs a lot of luggage‚Äô ? I‚Äôm not a super-lightweight cyclist by any means, but there are posts here that make me think, really, that much stuff ?
This was me and my buddies rigs for Canada - Mexico. Anymore than this just seems excessive to me, but some people like their comfort ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è to each their own
data.author: Jeff Roe

data.text: How many pounds are you carrying?
data.author: Ceecee Gowin

data.text: That's similar to my setup, but when I was younger, I brought a lot fewer "comfort" items.
data.author: Brian Huntley

data.text: That is very light touring. I carry more water and food because the areas I go to are extremely far from grocery stores and fresh water resources. I'm on tour right now... and couldn't find a clean source of water for 41 miles... and I drank 8 liters today and it's only 4pm. ü§∑üèΩ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
data.author: Javier Col√≥n

data.text: the metal bottles on my front fork could each hold a half gallon, plus my 2 squeeze bottles
data.author: Jeff Roe

data.text: like 25-35 pounds
data.author: Jeff Roe

data.text: Where is your food? Are you a cup of noodles guy?
data.author: Javier Col√≥n

data.text: with 2 bikes you can divide food, tools and cooking gear.
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: food in one pannier clothes and other stuff in the other.
data.author: Jeff Roe

data.text: hi. What are the hard cannisters on the sides.
data.author: Anthony Onewheelshort Ladd

data.text: I think they are just plastic buckets. Some people use them as panniers.
data.author: Jeff Roe

data.text: They started life as Kitty Litter buckets, but they're panniers now. They make a nice wide platform on top, are waterproof, and can be used as camp stools. They also have lots of space for reflective tape for visibility. What they are not is aerodynamic.
data.author: Brian Huntley

data.text: that last sentence gave me a laugh. I bet they‚Äôre cheaper than Ortlieb too.
data.author: Gareth Griffith

data.text: yea that last bit made me chuckle as well
data.author: Viktor Spett

data.text: As long as you have the strenght to carry it....
data.author: Paul Mailhiot

data.text: It does seem like some people really load up
data.author: Kent Robinson

data.text: When faced with any decision, lean towards minimal or multiuse.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: You do you and let them them do them. You're not having to ride their bikes so it's not your business
data.author: Rachel Katherine

data.text: I‚Äôm not judging Rachel. I‚Äôm really impressed by load-luggers. They‚Äôre probably much fitter than my old 60-year skeleton. Each to their own. Live & let pedal.
data.author: Graham Hood

data.text: absolutely so noone needs to judge eh
data.author: Rachel Katherine

data.text: When I wuz young, I wuz a minimal possession type person. Both when touring and life in general. Then I got old, the older I git, the more I carry. Creature comforts can be big. Like a chair fere instance. It's weight and space, but it can be life changing having a chair after a hard day's peddle. I also carry an air mattress now days. High maintenance fere sure.
data.author: Kawanta Lewis

data.text: 3 days is the same luggage as 3 months...my opinion anyway
data.author: Henrique Alves

data.text: - I beg to differ. Setting out for 3 days, you can check reliable forecast and pack accordingly to expected temperatures. For 3 months it could be hard. But I‚Äôd agree that 3 weeks and 3 months could be similar.
data.author: Marcin Kysiak

data.text: I‚Äôve yet to see (twin) duplicate setups. If I did, I probably would turn aroundü§® Including an individual‚Äôs road needs, A Tour is unique, personalüòÄ
data.author: Frank Preston

data.text: lol It's the age old story how much is to much? This is my set up a few years back on my London-Singapore trip. We cycled with a couple who was saying I cycled with to much stuff. They had 2 small dry bags on their forks and front ortliebs for their rear panniers. We then met another couple who joined our group. They had 4 large ortliebs each (front and rear) 2 ortlieb 49L rack packs EACH!! the 4 of us couldnt believe it and we ask ourselves what was in those bags. After a while the chap did ask if we wanted a full size tripod as he didn't think he needed 3!!!!! Then after a few days another tourer turned up and this on blew our minds he had a really light road bike with just 2 small front panniers on his rear, we kinda laughed a little at how he was going to get on with so less gear going through the Pamiers, we thought he was on a credit card tour what with his set up. To our amazement he has been on the road for 3 years he just needed less and less as the months went on. We also laughed a bit about his super light road bike until we came across sand and while we was struggling pushing our bikes he smiled put his whole set-up on his shoulders and and walked along with ease. The whole group got on well by the way and well all wondered just how each other got on with the different amount of stuff we all took with us.
data.author: Barry Warner

data.text:
Hi Barry. I'd be interested to know which route/countries you took. I rode there from Milton Keynes in 2014/15. Due to Iran's political border closure, at one point (in Georgia) there amounted to ten of us, three Mancunian lads cycling to Oz, an English/Oz couple cycling to Oz, a Spaniard, Lithuanian, & a Danish couple, great memories. http://wallisonwheels.blogspot.com
England to Singapore
wallisonwheels.blogspot.com
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: You did it a year before me.....I was folowing you to keep up my happiness while saving, thanks. My blog, it's not very good but it's mine :-) http://www.crazyguyonabike.com/doc/barrycuda
data.author: Barry Warner

data.text: Are you planning any more trips?
data.author: Barry Warner

data.text: As you say, it's [your] blog & that's what counts my friend. I occasionally re-read my blogs & chuckle to myself at things that happened & sights I saw, memories for life, & they're what count.
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text:
Well that was my 2nd, and done a third since, I'd still like to ride the eastern side of Africa, MK to Cairo to Cape Town, & also India, Bangladesh, Myanmar, but for now stay close for my parents as they're both getting on...mum's 80th b.day this Saturday üòâ How about yourself, anything planned? This was my 3rd; https://wallisonwheelz.blogspot.com/
Argentina to Alaska
wallisonwheelz.blogspot.com
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: Yup you was following in my tyre marks as I had done London to Capetown back in 1998. I followed you for your England-Singpore and once again will be following your tracks in South America I will fly to Cambodia and start southwards 1st April next year. Happy birthday to your mum. After South America I also think Africa calls, will be nice to see the change 25 years or so makes.
data.author: Barry Warner

data.text: That's a neat set-up Barry and kudos for the Hawaiin shirt too !
data.author: Graham Hood

data.text: the most important piece of kit you can take on a tour is a Hawain shirt :-)
data.author: Barry Warner

data.text: must confess I have packed two, which I know is one too many!
data.author: Fintan Culwin

data.text: Cheers! Free cake & beer if you turn up üòÑ My Americas tour was 2016-18 Barry, north from Ushuaia, reaching San Fran after one year, then east to New York following the historic Lincoln Highway, it pre-dates Route 66 by a good few years with so much to see, then onto to Lubec, the furthest easterly US town, from there into Canada back west to Vancouver, Canada was bloody amazing!! Which route did you take to Cape Town? I still intend to ride the eastern side.
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: Yep every time!
data.author: Simon Dodding

data.text: All the time. ü§∑üèΩ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è I've been kicked out of several bicycle touring groups because I don't hesitate to point out ridiculous rigs and excessive luggage or bad bicycle choices for tours. You cannot give any criticism to people these days... üôÑ but it's certainly going to make for an inconvenient bicycle ride.
data.author: Javier Col√≥n

data.text: All the time. My cross country gear, camping and cooking my own food, is 15lbs. More power to them if they can carry all the weight but not for me.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: I've now completed three extended tours using two large rear panniers & two small front, along with rack top bag. Total approximate weight all-in is ~ 60kg, food & water extra, no complaints from me. Here I am en-route to Iguazo Falls, an amazing place to see!
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: There is no right or wrong here. It's not a race, it's not a fashion show, it doesnt matter what kind of bike someone rides. As long they enjoy themselves, who cares?
data.author: Jake Klamerus

data.text: exactly. What another biker does is none of my business. I‚Äôm not the one pedaling someone else‚Äôs bike up a hill! üòÇ
data.author: Adrienne Albright Lehtinen

data.text: absolutely!
data.author: Debs Mutton

data.text: Take as much or as little as you are comfortable carrying. Its surprising what you can do without. I often mix hobbies so, sometimes carry more than i would carry on a regular bike camping trip. Other times, i carry just the basics ( as i will this weekend)
data.author: Michael Richards

data.text: I absolutely agree. Take the minimum of clothing leaving space for a couple of treats, as it can be washed or double up the usage. My small North Face feather coat is my pillow too.
data.author: Mandy Lock Krumins

data.text: yeah, but I bet it cost a fortune. North Face are a famous brand that is COINING it in. You are basically spending $50 for a stitched lable...
data.author: David Eldred

data.text: Tale of two setups. On the left is my Iceland rig from last summer, on the right is the Gulf Coast this spring. A few more creature comforts added
data.author: Mike Pribesh

data.text: I guess it depends how far you‚Äôre going and how frequently you can shop.
data.author: Geoffrey Silverstein

data.text: Yes, you are not the only one. Others often look at my bike judging and giving advice what I should have done to take less or should have get rid of. Sometimes even they forget to ask simple polite questions, they are so busy talking about my luggage. But I've been touring for 8,5 years. I know what I need.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: where are you now ü§îü§îü§îü•∞
data.author: Georges Augusto

data.text: Made my day, thanks!
data.author: Ste Ierace

data.text: Italy. Does it matter?
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: that's not a very polite answer. And you just saying how people don't ask simple polite questions...
data.author: David Eldred

data.text: it is just as it was meant to be. You van call it ironic or sacastic, yes. Showing how irritating and unappropriate I find it to discuss what I carry. And it has nothing to do with politeness meaning "hello, where are you from, where do you go" instead of "you carry far too much" that I hear. It looks many other feel that way.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: yes, but you were still being quite rude, Okay...
data.author: David Eldred

data.text: ok.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: don't you Okay me. It's the bloke from Switzerland you need to openly apoligise to...
data.author: David Eldred

data.text: ouch
data.author: Mary Cosentino-Cathey

data.text: Yes. I am often surprised to see how people look like hoarders on wheels, pretending to need this for their "expedition" where they camp in a forest that is just 15 miles from the nearest grocery store and coffee shop, where the rest of us tour cyclists are sitting with a quarter of their luggage üôÇ.
data.author: Claus Andersen

data.text: Ride your own ride.
data.author: Kevin Michael

data.text: Whoops. Did not mean to offend anyone. Just wanted a discussion. Stay safe people...
data.author: Graham Hood

data.text: literally every post on FB is offensive to someone regardless of content so wouldn‚Äôt worry about that üòä
data.author: James Mckoy

data.text: Yep üòä
data.author: James Mckoy

data.text: Ya. I am that guy. Did an overnighter a few weeks ago with full bags. I plan to cut my weight a lot for my next ride which will longer and harder.
data.author: Anthony Onewheelshort Ladd

data.text: I guess the question you really need to ask is "does this affect me?", if the answer is a resounding "no", then move on because it's irrelevant.
data.author: Wayne M

data.text: Irony?
data.author: Andy Anderson

data.text: indeed!
data.author: Wayne M

data.text: Absolutely! I'm by no means a weight weenie, my bikepacking kit is 90% the same as what i use for 3 season hiking trips and comes in at 7.5kgs. ( I could shave off 2kg but that would mean buying $$$$ gear) Add to that water, fuel, food, toolkit, the bags themselves...I mean, it quickly adds up. If i see ppl rocking 4 panniers and a duffelbag on top...i couldn't handle it. Respect!
data.author: Pilecki Dave

data.text: My actual luggage isn't a lot, but 2 weeks of food fill the panniers easily
data.author: Benjamin Moravec

data.text: when would you ever need 2 weeks of food
data.author: Jeff Roe

data.text: when I want to be in nature for 2 weeks, which is often.
data.author: Benjamin Moravec

data.text: Fairbanks to Prudhoe Bay, about 500 miles, one cafe, that‚Äôs it.
data.author: Linda Lynch

data.text: I guess it's my far-back experiences as a touring kayaker, where space and weight are at a premium, and food and water take pecedence, and the stability of the kayak was also a consideration. Yes, we had a certain 'odour' due to restrictions on clothing. Nothing a dip in the river could not cure though.
data.author: Graham Hood

data.text: Some of us ride for months at a time, through different seasons‚Ä¶
data.author: Tara Tompkins

data.text: I look like an overpacker and have been accused of such. Four panniers and a handlebar bag lets me distribute mass, if not volume. My sleeping bag is huge. I don't care. It works for me. I I need about one pannier per two nights, so an 8 night trip requires four panniers. Less than that, well, just what ARE you packing? But I do not understand the need for trailers and think that trailers insult the engineering of the bike. (Why, yes! That IS a target on my back! Why do you ask?) Next trip - Waterloo, Ontario, Canada, to Ottawa, and back, via Toronto, Pembroke and Orillia. (Four bagger, for sure!)
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: about 10 years ago my son, wife, and I took a road tour in Bavaria. I pulled gear for the family. The trailer worked out really well. They have a place, but on my own I prefer bicycle bags.
data.author: Anthony Onewheelshort Ladd

data.text: I did the same thing when my kids were 5 and 7. I get it. It's the people packing four panniers, a handlebar bag a frame bag AND a trailer that confuse me. (They must live in a flat world, is all I know for sure!)
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: If I had 4 panniers, I would fill them up - unfortunately. In cold weather, I definitely carry more - sometimes 2 sleeping bags. I only do 2 or 3 months at a time, but I think if I were traveling continuously, I might be inclined to carry more because then it's your home, your life. And, more importantly, I enjoy the hills so weight is an issue.
data.author: Marshall Bradbury

data.text: Gotta be comfortable. Everyone is different!
data.author: Mike McAuley

data.text: Each to their own but after decades of carrying hiking packs, I'm in the habit of taking the minimum.
data.author: Pete Myers

data.text: All depends on how long and far you are going. When planning an open ended (multi year) tour we took books (for reading and learning a completely new language), juggling balls (because I wanted to learn how to juggle 4 balls), running shoes etc (because wanting a decent run ever so often) and at some stages snorkeling-gear, an eski ( to keep ants out of food) or even a cast iron sandwichmaker to use over a fire....no issue really, compared to carrying 15 litres of water anyway. Bit different from doing a couple a weeks of touring though when we go lightweight
data.author: Jurg Mudd

data.text: Everyone is different for sure. Filmmaking is just as big of a hobby as cycling is to me, so I have an entire pannier bag filled with camera and editing gear so I can film and edit on the journey. Practical? No. Would I change anything? Nope!
data.author: Matt Hollman
David Yemm

data.text: Before any judgement is made, we'd have to look at the clutter or lack thereof in their home/minds. I tend to carry some 30 kg of gear (plus water, food), but that's because I've been 11 years on the road, so to speak, and sometimes have the intention of staying longer in some places where I might need certain documents. It's also just "housekeeping" laziness. Also some double or redundant stuff (two cell/smart phones, two camping gas cooker thingies because in some countries the cartridges are not available for one or the other device, a spare pair of reading glasses, etc.). Maybe with right planning I could lighten my load by 25%. Then I have things I hardly ever need but as they say, better to have it and not need it than to need it and not have it," like sewing material, first-aid or painkillers, tools, etc. Although they are not expensive, it saves time and headaches, searching for it in the bags rather than going out to shops to find/buy them again. For example, a long piece of rope. I've only used it once or twice but I was glad to have it when I needed it.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: Compact and light gear is expensive, not everyone can afford it. Not everyone is trying to ride 100 miles a day either. I think the people with all sorts of things strapped to their bike are nuts, but will support them all the same.
data.author: Jeremy Francis

data.text: And I am sure most of us used to carry more gear than we do now., or will carry in the future if we are new to touring.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: A Zen master would say "leting go is not easy, but if you want to go higher, on the path, you should".
data.author: Mahesh T Pai

data.text: isn't that Yoda??üòÑüòÑ
data.author: Virginia Yurisich

data.text: Fuck going light! Bring whatever makes you happy! If you use it it's worth it! Try to be all light then some one gives you 5kg of mangos, what are you gonna do, say no?
data.author: Maxwell Seward Young

data.text: indeed! Someone gave us ten pounds of candy once. We love our sweets and what‚Äôs another few pounds on a loaded bike üòÇ
data.author: Adrienne Albright Lehtinen

data.text: Judge not! People sometimes start out heavy and pare it down as time goes on and they jettison stuff. It‚Äôs part of the process. Also, if it‚Äôs cold at the start of a trip and lots of bulky clothes are needed, than can make the packs look fat!
data.author: Ed Weingarten

data.text: It's just you.üòâ
data.author: Noreen May Light

data.text: I once found a pair of my wife‚Äôs high heels in one of my panniers. She claimed she had put them in on our shakedown tour to substitute for something or other - but 12 years later, I‚Äôm still not sure I believe her.
data.author: Graeme Maher

data.text: My wife and I have done both. 4 Ortlieb panniers each on our tour of Northern Norway, and more recently 2 rear panniers between us when we do two weekers in Thailand or Malaysia - where we currently live.
data.author: Graeme Maher

data.text: On my first tour through Europe I was carrying camping gear and hated it because the bike frame was flexing and it was heavy. Campgrounds were not much cheaper than staying in the youth hostel so I didn't really camp anyway. As soon as I stopped at the post office and posted my camping gear home I felt much more comfortable and ever since I've been touring by using warm showers or other cyclist networks or staying in youth hostels. If others want to do free camping or go more remote then that's a different story but I like the experience of staying with people and staying relatively close to civilisation. Not sure if this disqualifies me as a touring cyclist, but that's the way I do it. I admire people who are more self-reliant but I don't mind borrowing things or buying them if I have to.
data.author: Michael Noske

data.text: 21 days in Europe along the Rhine a few years ago
data.author: Jeff Stone

data.text: It's not just you... Sometime I look at pics of loaded bikes and I say to myself.. How can anyone ride with this small hill on him? The balance is crazy.. Uphill is a turture.. Not for me. I am here for the fun.. üëªüëª
data.author: ◊ê◊®◊ê ◊í◊ï◊®◊ü

data.text: Yep üëç
data.author: Ramon Gacio

data.text: Panniers are like wardrobes. If you have them you will fill them üòÅ
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: Not everyone walks (rides) around judging people. You don't know their circumstances, the length of their tour, the regions or seasons they'll be in, or what they are carrying and why. I had to add 2 rear panniers because I was gifted a mirrorless Sony with a 20-70mm and a 70-200mm lenses - they fill an entire back pannier. I also carry my laptop. Need both to earn money. Been on the road for +4 years. If I was to do a weekend bikepacking trip, I would just need a seat post 6L bag. My bike, my body, my choice. Go ride and focus on you. Try to judge less. Fill your mind of other thoughts to occupy your time with
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: I have been recently traveling with a 25L backpack (1month+ trip, including a week on a bike). Doable? Absolutely. Well, that is, doable on an island that has a warm and predictable climate, if there are places for me to rent a room. Because if it was colder, I‚Äôd need warmer clothes, if it was winter, that would include a bulky jacket. If I was camping, I‚Äôd need camping gear, food, and water. We need lots of water... If I was more serious about photography and filming, that would add extra gear. And all those ifs add extra liters. And those are just the most obvious ones.
data.author: Kay Anky JS

data.text: Have a look at "cycling the world " on instagram or YouTube . Jin also has surfboard strapped to side
data.author: Paul John Markham

data.text: Most people set off with far too much stuff and end up ditching stuff on the way. Yes I am guilty of this!
data.author: Fern Hume

data.text: I think as you get more experience you only take what's necessary, my first tour was four bags packed with many useless items, now I bike pack with far less about 7 kilos or 8 if I take the tent instead of the bivvy.
data.author: Roy Harvey

data.text: It's all relative. Many people pack more in journeys expected to be wet or cold or both. People pack more that believe (And are often wrong) that they wouldn't be able to pick the item up where theyare going. (I'm referrring people that carry extra TYRES!) I mean, you can go thousands of miles on your tyres, and you usually replace the rear for the front if you are sensible. Then you find a place that sells tyres...
data.author: David Eldred

data.text: I look at these posts a lot and think the same thing all the time.. I remind myself I'm glad its not me.
data.author: Craig Martin

data.text: I've met a lot of people on a tour who tell me they shipped stuff they didn't need back home after riding a few days. It's probably better to pack only what you'll need, but if shipping stuff home, or giving it away, is an option, it's not a big deal to carry a bunch of stuff initially.
data.author: Scott J. Mansfield

data.text: I used to run with 5kg Inc tent sleeping bag and some food. I ride with about 12 kg now. Who cares each to their own. If you are riding alone the camping/ cooking gear is more weight spares etc
data.author: John Axson

data.text: I think it will depend on the level of confort. If you are going for a long time cycling (more than 3 months) sometimes the little luxury makes a difference to keep you going.
data.author: Erocita Alvarez

data.text: Why are you judging. Everyone has diverse imperatives. You do yourself, I will ride & learn my own may, and all will be well on the journeys to unravel & travel.
data.author: Gracie Trish

data.text: We are going to tour south island in NZ in January. I haven't done this since I was 22 and I'm a grandmother now. I'm so getting into what people bring. It's not much., but really in summer you dont need much
data.author: Lesley Hardy

data.text: Yes, I used to cut the extra bolt lengths and hacksaw the drop bars. Uphill fast is so much more fun. A lot easier to carry all that through French train stations too. Go light, go fast and experience more.
data.author: Stuart McDonald

data.text: I like my bbq and nobody is gonna stop me taking it.
data.author: Trevor Grigson

data.text: When Europeans visit on bikes they often bring clothes for other activities like seeing a play, church (well probably not), or perhaps even some other sport. That requires extra stuff. I always ask Warmshowers guests why the heavy load and the answers are always reasonable.
data.author: David Frederick

data.text: This post makes me chuckle. Two-thirds of the way around Australia with a finely tuned set of essential requirements we met a another touring cyclist who was travelling from Adelaide to Perth, who promptly informed us that we were carrying way too much gear. Further conversation elicited that he was in fact a teacher, and suddenly, everything became crystal-clear.
data.author: John Dow

data.text: I think it's down to the riders. We are on a RTW trip so have kit for cold weather as well as dry. Certainly needed it these last few days. We each have front and rear panniers plus a holdall on the rear. Mine are pretty much half full but room for extra water and food for remote areas. Tom carries his toys! Decent camera, gopro, computer and drone plus electrics to keep them working. Other kit is at an absolute minimum, honest üòâüòÇ
data.author: Debs Mutton

data.text: It all depends. In a few months and a few thousand kilometres, weather can vary from tropical to snow. Trying to send shit from place to place just you can travel light is sometimes just not worth the headache. Plus fuck it, I'm touring to enjoy myself, not to prove a point/tick boxes/cover miles. That's why my bike is built like a brick shit house and my gear solid and functional. It gets stuffed in a box at the start of each trip, and the bits tipped out on the ground at some airport.
data.author: Trevor Grigson

data.text: Run front low rider panniers as well as back panniers , also full frame bag ,also computer , camera , solar charger am not one to factor in towns ,am self sufficient love roads less travelled Aussie bush. my advice worry about packing your bike we know what we are doing üòé
data.author: Ron Nettleton

data.text: I drink 5 liters of water on average per day. I prefer to carry enough for 2 days and that's 10kgs of water alone... Personal and camping gear comes in at about 12kgs because I go for full size comfortable air mattress and thick sleeping bag and 2 persons tent, plus 2 clothing for 3 days.. it's my long term travel comfort. Throw in some food and easily I hit over 30kgs. I'm often ready to haul 40kgs if need be on long term trips and my daily target cycling distance is only about 60km a day... And despite what I carry and how slow I go, I always exceed my travel targets and see more and explore. So yes, I understand the idea of weight, but everyone can have a reason I guess.... In my opinion, any weight under 50kgs for a long term Traveller, it's nothing
data.author: Kyagera Ivan

data.text: I think that about my own luggage, especially when riding up hills ...
data.author: Simon Lambourn
